snippet: Our colleagues Rachel Donadio and Niki Kitsantonis report from Athens that Finance Minister Evangelos Venizelos left for a meeting of his European counterparts in Brussels on Thursday morning, even though Greek political leaders had failed so far to...
abstract: Our colleagues Rachel Donadio and Niki Kitsantonis report from Athens that Finance Minister Evangelos Venizelos left for a meeting of his European counterparts in Brussels on Thursday morning, even though Greek political leaders had failed so far to reach an agreement on austerity measures demanded by Greece's financial backers. If the leaders do not sign an agreement, lenders will not give Greece the aid it needs to avoid default. Even as Mr. Venizelos appealed to the politicians for the umpteenth time, saying that their decisions "will determine whether the country remains in the eurozone or whether its place in Europe will be endangered," the line between Greek political theater and international financial trauma was difficult to discern. Read Rachel and Niki's article»
lead_paragraph: Our colleagues Rachel Donadio and Niki Kitsantonis report from Athens that Finance Minister Evangelos Venizelos left for a meeting of his European counterparts in Brussels on Thursday morning, even though Greek political leaders had failed so far to reach an agreement on austerity measures demanded by Greece's financial backers. If the leaders do not sign an agreement, lenders will not give Greece the aid it needs to avoid default. Even as Mr. Venizelos appealed to the politicians for the umpteenth time, saying that their decisions "will determine whether the country remains in the eurozone or whether its place in Europe will be endangered," the line between Greek political theater and international financial trauma was difficult to discern. Read Rachel and Niki's article»

headline.main: Greek Finance Minister Goes to Brussels, Without Political Accord at Home
